Jun 14, 2016

Design in healthcare: beyond the patient-centered approach

When we talk about design in healthcare, we first of all talk about human connection, compassion and empathy. In many cases health is a sensitive topic for many of us, and it’s vastly a design challenge — to create an environment that would feel inviting and safe enough to start a sincere conversation between a doctor and a patient, or even of a patient with themselves.

Since design started to permeate healthcare, we’ve seen a shift in the industry towards compassion and sympathy. Hospitals have been getting rid of “hospital smell”, injections being replaced by plasters, more and more pills taste like candy. There are hundreds of health and wellness apps that look no worse than the latest versions of VSCO or Evernote. Health stepped out of the shadow and became a part of our lifestyle, it became humane and trendy.

When we talk about deep emotional understanding in healthcare, we immediately think of patients — as the ones who need support and comfort in their most fragile and vulnerable moments. Patient-centered approach has been the central principle of healthcare design. But all this time, in the same room have been people who need to be understood no less than patients: doctors.

For most of us (hopefully), visiting hospitals is not something that we do every day. In the times when we have to deal with our health problems, we necessarily want to be heard and helped. For healthcare practitioners — acting on empathy, attention and understanding are daily routines. All in addition to hacking diseases, learning new medications, and long hours of research on patient cases. Unlike patients who have gained access to great health apps, doctors haven’t felt any relief on the hospital software.

Regardless of all the technical progress and design thinking leaking into the industry, in most cases healthcare software remains clunky and poorly designed. While user apps are getting more easy-to-use and sleek, enterprise software remains cumbersome and confusing, featuring poor UI and awkward interaction flaws. In the industry where life and death hang in the balance, good usability can not be an option. It’s a necessity.

The problem, we guess, is in the nature of both the software and the industry. Healthcare platforms, especially EMRs and collaboration tools, usually don’t work as stand alone programs and are connected to other systems. They feed and are being fed information from other platforms. Naturally, such software takes longer to develop, fix and update. Barriers to entry are high, and development is costly. In the end, healthcare software is produced by “monolithic” IT companies with prevailing engineering mindset that have been on the market for a while. The result is the software with non-intuitive workflows, cluttered data-entry screens, and information presented in illogical formats.

Now let’s jump into the shoes of a physician. In addition to examining patients, performing diagnostic tests and treating illnesses, they keep and update patient’s health records, read tons of papers, and attend professional conferences. Many of them suffer burnouts and exhaustion, as they continue to work at home having 16-hour workdays for years.

Dealing with hospital software is a big part of a physician’s work. Technology is penetrating all areas of healthcare, starting with electronic medical records and ending up with digital pathology, surgery robots and telemedicine. Ideally, every technological novice entering the hospital walls should integrate seamlessly into the workflow, saving doctors’ time and efforts. In reality, it often arrives with a 20-page manual and a couple of video tutorials.

As many other industries, healthcare needs to be redesigned. Healthcare has centuries of history and accumulated knowledge, its progress is evolutionary, avoiding radical breakthroughs. Learning from failure is something you’d rather not talk about in healthcare. In short, it is a tough environment to work in, when you are in a business of innovation.

On the other end, designers live in an opposite universe — agile, flexible and fast-paced. They have their own history, but it’s a history of change and innovation, trial and error. When these 2 worlds face each other — reaching perfect mutual comprehension is essential. Designer’s task in this case is not just to solve a specific usability problem, but also to bring back trust into tech on the behalf of healthcare practitioners as well as to stress their role of problem-solvers and idea generators.

As our team set about to work on an oncology informatics project for a client, they spent days and weeks observing closely the hospital environment in a dozen clinics and hospitals around the world. The team visited tumour boards and procedure rooms, experimented with microscopes to exam tissue slides and shadowed clinicians throughout their working days. Understanding behaviours and workflows was very important at the initial stage.

For example, the language that physicians use. As the team was conducting in-depth interviews, they noticed that some words don’t really get through clinician’s understanding. Words like “imagination”, “experimentation” and “failure” seemed to sound vague or uncertain to a physician’s ear. In the end, the wording was tweaked and its elements were replaced with the closest ones from doctors’ vocabulary — like “testing” or “examination”. These minor changes made communication much easier and reinforced client trust in the team.

The team were also paying attention to how doctors exchange information among themselves. For example, at one of the initial phases the team observed that doctors in some hospitals use popular messaging apps like Viber or WhatsApp to consult each other on patient’s cases. For designers it meant that doctors were well familiar with the chat interface. It also inferred that the current communication tool within the system was not convenient enough. Finally, it could mean that the doctors didn’t want the discussion process to be traceable or public until they reached the final conclusion. This observation provided valuable clues on how to facilitate communication among doctors through the info sharing platform that the team was currently working on.

When learnings from field studies turned into conclusions, action points and designs, the team made basic prototypes and ran user testing with the doctors at the clinic. The problem of many existing medical platforms is that actual users are the last ones to test the product when it’s already made. Engaging physicians into the process allowed them to feel like product owners and their voice was heard and valued. At Impossible Labs we run user testing almost every month as a final part of a design sprint.

To make patient-centered design work, we should fix the doctor-centered design first. We should be designing tools for doctors with empathy and compassion in mind, as doctors need to be understood no less than patients. You simply can’t draw water from a dry well.

Impact is the only criteria by which design is measured. And in this case impactful is a solution that frees the doctor from the burden of bureaucracy and note-taking and allows them to spend more time and energy on talking to and understanding patients.

Enjoyed reading this? Get to know more about Evidence-Based Design!
